newsitem.title: USA: Plains feedlot cattle trade at standstill -private.
newsitem.headline: Plains feedlot cattle trade at standstill -private.

text.p: Plains feedlot cattle markets just ahead of midday Thursday were quiet, with no sales of slaughter steers or heifers reported, feedlot sources said.
Most showlists were sold out during this week's active trading that broke week-to-date volume records in the Texas Panhandle/western Oklahoma and Kansas.
The majority of this week's sales took place Tuesday at $68.00 per cwt, up $2.00 from a week ago.
Owners were now pricing cattle at $69.00 to $70.00 for the handful of remaining cattle, but packer inquiry was generally light and cattle feeders were passing the bids.
Feedlot cattle prices this week were boosted by a rebound in boxed beef prices which spurred buying by packers who were short of live inventories, the sources said.
Boxed beef prices at midday were quoted up $0.14 to $0.36 per cwt, with the choice heavyweight value up $0.26 at $104.92, USDA said. There were 193 fabricated loads sold.
Projections for increasingly tighter feedlot cattle supplies the next four weeks also fueled the competitive bidding that kicked prices higher, sources said.
